title: Are the original Beatrix Potter illustrations now out of Copyright? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some are, some aren't. Depends on where (as in US or Europe) you're publishing, and the date in which whatever you picked to copy, was distributed in the US. Sound interesting legal contest here.The Tale of One Bunny, Copyright Statements, & Public Domain: A Cautionary Tail Sound confusing? It is.

Beatrix Potter died in 1943. In many (most?) countries, works of someone who died more than 70 years ago are in the public domain (i.e., out of copyright). Works published prior to 1923 in the United States are in the public domain in the U.S. That would include many of Potter's illustrations.

It’s my understanding that works more than 60 years old enter into the public domain, unless the right to that work is assigned to someone upon the artist’s death. My guess is that inheirited rights to a work would need to be periodically renewed.
